To ...

attachments.displayName:
In the song "Cults of the Shadows" they sing:
The Seven Ones of Babel
Offer the Grail of Ecstasy
To open the Eye of Shiva
Through the Great Work of Ecstasy.

Perhaps, "The Seven Ones of Babel" means Apkallu - in the Akkadian-Sumerian mythology are seven Sumerian sages, demigods who are said to have been created by the god Enki to establish culture and give civilization to mankind. They also were the founders of first seven Sumerian cities.

According to the myth, human beings were initially unaware of the benefits of culture and civilization. The god Enki sent from Dilmun, amphibious half-fish, half-human creatures, who emerged from the oceans to live with the early human beings and teach them the arts and other aspects of civilization such as writing, law, temple and city building and agriculture. These creatures are known as the Apkallu. The Apkallu remained with human beings after teaching them the ways of civilization, and served as advisers to the kings.

Also, Adapa is considered to be one of them. Adapa, the first of the Mesopotamian seven sages, unknowingly refused the gift of immortality.

object.content:
In the song "Cults of the Shadows" they sing:
The Seven Ones of Babel
Offer the Grail of Ecstasy
To open the Eye of Shiva
Through the Great Work of Ecstasy.

Perhaps, "The Seven Ones of Babel" means Apkallu - in the Akkadian-Sumerian mythology are seven Sumerian sages, demigods who are said to have been created by the god Enki to establish culture and give civilization to mankind. They also were the founders of first seven Sumerian cities.

According to the myth, human beings were initially unaware of the benefits of culture and civilization. The god Enki sent from Dilmun, amphibious half-fish, half-human creatures, who emerged from the oceans to live with the early human beings and teach them the arts and other aspects of civilization such as writing, law, temple and city building and agriculture. These creatures are known as the Apkallu. The Apkallu remained with human beings after teaching them the ways of civilization, and served as advisers to the kings.

Also, Adapa is considered to be one of them. Adapa, the first of the Mesopotamian seven sages, unknowingly refused the gift of immortality.
